03

We have officially entered the Age of Artificial Intelligence. The world is now 
set to change at a pace not seen in decades, even centuries. AI-based tools and 
applications make our lives easier, smoother, and richer. They help us move efficiently, 
get informed, get credit, get a job, and get our taxes done.
But in its current form, AI reproduces and amplifies many of the social challenges we face. It is not acceptable that 
around a third of the world’s population still lacks adequate internet access. Upstream, the AI industry is highly 
concentrated, with just two countries – the United States and China – and a dozen companies accounting for a 
major share of the sector. This can lead only to greater inequality of outcomes – including gender disparities – 
downstream. Non-diverse AI teams, unrepresentative datasets, and opaque and biased algorithms can cause harm, 
particularly to those who are already vulnerable, whether companies or individuals, children and young people, 
women, or entire democracies.
That is why UNESCO drafted the Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, which was adopted in 2021 
by 193 countries to make sure AI delivers fair, sustainable, and inclusive outcomes. The Recommendation is based 
on the protection and promotion of human rights, human dignity, and environmental sustainability, and these 
values are then translated into principles such as accountability, transparency, and privacy. The Recommendation 
also sets out concrete policy actions that governments can draw on to steer technological developments in a 
responsible direction, premised on the belief that light-touch regulation, which has until now remained the norm, is 
insufficient. We need capable governments that are well equipped, in terms of competencies, institutions and laws, 
to frame responsible AI development and protect the rule of law online, and public and private developers who are 
accountable for putting human rights and fundamental freedoms – not profits or geopolitical considerations – first.
Foreword
Lidia Brit

recommendations.title:
Laws and regulations
Ethics and AI governance framework
recommendations.text: The multidisciplinary AI Ethics Think Tank proposed in December 2023 and formalized in February 2025 to

recommendations.title: oversee the implementation of the UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of AI must develop and enforce
recommendations.text: ethical guidelines to ensure AI deployment aligns with Zimbabwe’s values and priorities. The think tank must also institutionalize procedures for ongoing participation and engagement from key stakeholders, such as MDAs, academia, civil society, and international bodies like UNESCO. Responsible institutions: The following institutions would play important roles in the process of formalizing the AI Ethics Think Tank: • Ministry of Information Communication Technology, Postal and Courier Services •

recommendations.title:
Open data directive 
Zimbabwe needs a legally binding Open Data Directive, enacted under the Data Protection Act, mandating that
recommendations.text: non-personal public sector data be made available for public use. This directive must cover national, regional, and

recommendations.title:
a regulatory framework that promotes innovation by enabling access to data that fuels AI development while 
maintaining strong data protection and privacy standards. This would strengthen the capacity to create and
recommendations.text: maintain high-quality, reliable data sets, such as cultural heritage datasets, while ensuring data sovereignty, security

recommendations.title: establishing an Open Data Directive:
recommendations.text: • Ministry of Information Communication Technology, Postal and Courier Services (coordinating ministry). •

recommendations.title: Ministry of Justice, Legal and Parliamentary Affairs

recommendations.text: • National Museums and Monuments Department •

recommendations.title: Ministry of Home Affairs
recommendations.text: Timeline: 2025

recommendations.title:
Development and harmonization of AI-related laws and policies
Several key pieces of legislation in Zimbabwe already lay a foundation for AI policy, addressing areas like data 
protection, cybersecurity, ICT policy, consumer protection, digital transformation, and innovation. The government
recommendations.text: must audit, if necessary, develop or review, and harmonize these laws by aligning them with AI’s unique challenges and opportunities. Zimbabwe can create a strategic framework that guides AI technologies’ ethical, responsible,

recommendations.title:
and inform global discussions on the use of AI in law enforcement, for example, addressing bias and discrimination 
in facial recognition technologies, and in the military, for example, the use of algorithms and AI-enabled decision
recommendations.text: support systems. Responsible institutions: The following institutions would play relevant roles in the process of harmonizing existing

recommendations.title: legislation to support AI development and deployment:
recommendations.text: • Ministry of Information Communication Technology, Postal and Courier Services • The Zimbabwean Parliament • Postal and Telecommunications Regulatory Authority of Zimbabwe (POTRAZ) •

recommendations.title: Ministries of Home Affairs and Defence.
recommendations.text: • Relevant civil society organisations Timeline: 2025 45

recommendations.title:
Institutional frameworks and governance
National AI strategy coordination
To maximize the benefits of AI while mitigating risks, Zimbabwe requires a comprehensive national AI strategy that
recommendations.text: builds on its existing legislative and policy frameworks. A comprehensive national AI strategy should be drafted to

recommendations.title: ensure a coordinated and transparent approach to AI governance that on the one hand reflect Zimbabwe’s shared
recommendations.text: values, norms, and aspirations and on the other hand the transnational nature of AI. This strategy must include a clearly defined organogram with specified roles for each responsible institution/stakeholder. Additionally, there must

recommendations.title:
be standard procedures for engaging civil society, academia, and industry in the development and implementation 
of AI policies.
recommendations.text: Responsible institutions: The following institutions/stakeholders would play relevant roles in developing and

recommendations.title: adopting a national AI strategy:
recommendations.text: • Ministry of Information Communication Technology, Postal and Courier Services •

Scientific and Industrial Research and Development Centre
recommendations.text: • UNESCO • Civil society groups • Postal and Telecommunications Regulatory Authority of Zimbabwe (POTRAZ) • Office of the President and the Cabinet. Timeline: 2025

recommendations.title:
Data governance and coordination
Clear data governance structures must be established to define the roles of stakeholders in data collection, storage,
recommendations.text: protection, and sharing, especially in relation to AI readiness indicators. These procedures must prioritize open-

recommendations.title: The proposed AI Ethics Think Tank
recommendations.text: • POTRAZ • Zimbabwe National Statistics Agency • Ministry of Health and Child Care of Zimbabwe • Academic institutions • OECD • World Bank • ITU Timeline: 2025 46 Capacity building Zimbabwe’s development of a human capital plan could attract investment in AI infrastructure and spur discussions on its environmental implications. It would also evaluate the effects of AI and automation on the workforce, business, government processes (e-government), and establish job retraining programmes.

recommendations.title:
Education and public engagement on AI policies
Government departments must collaborate with the AI Ethics Think Tank to raise public awareness about AI-related
recommendations.text: policies, including Zimbabwe’s Digital Strategy, 4IR Strategy, and e-Health frameworks. A national public education and

recommendations.title: outreach plan should be developed to ensure that the public and private sectors are informed about AI standards and
recommendations.text: their practical implications. Additionally, there is a need to update curricula for primary and secondary schools to include

Zimbabwe Council for Higher Education

recommendations.title:
Inclusive AI workforce development and infrastructural support
The national AI strategy must prioritise socio-economic inclusion by ensuring that AI policy promotes gender equality,
recommendations.text: cultural and linguistic diversity, and addresses the evolving labour market. Measures should be taken to retain and attract a skilled workforce, while also preventing “brain drain”. The government could, for example, continue to invest in the Presidential Scholarship Programme. The strategy should establish mechanisms for the ongoing evaluation of inclusion and

recommendations.title: to address potential job displacement caused by AI, including retraining programmes and support for affected workers.
recommendations.text: In addition, there is a need to establish an enabling environment for infrastructural support and coordination in AI

recommendations.title:
development by investing in and upgrading technological infrastructure, such as data centres, telecommunication and 
computer networks, open science cloud, virtual and augmented reality to facilitate AI research and deployment. The
recommendations.text: government should continue to drive policy implementation as contained in the National ICT Policy to facilitate public-

recommendations.title: private-partnerships as an approach to enable empowerment of local firms to participate in the development of the ICT
recommendations.text: sector and use of new material. This can partly be achieved by granting Special Economic Zone status to ICT technology parks. Responsible institutions: • Ministry of Information Communication Technology, Postal and Courier Services •

legal_regulatory.title: Legal and Regulatory
findings: Legal and regulatory AI policy and regulation 14 ### Page 17 The 2017 e-Health Strategy The strategy identifies opportunities for drawing on data to support decisions in the industry while ensuring patient control over personal data use (Zimbabwe’s E-Health Strategy, p.24)3.

National population registry data policy Zimbabwe’s Ministry of Home Affairs and Cultural Heritage in September 2023 announced that a process is underway to upgrade the Zimbabwe Population Registry System (ZPRS) and link it to several vital government services, making it possible to apply for docume
The ZPRS is the central database containing all Zimbabwean citizens’ biographical and biometric data.
It is crucial to note that such improvement would require access to highly sensitive personal data and thus would have to be governed by the Cyber and Data Protection Act.

Data protection and privacy laws The Cyber and Data Protection Act8 (CPDA) provides the foundational guidance for the collection, storage, use and transfer of data, including the privacy of genetic, biometric, sensitive, and health data.
It serves as a foundational legislation to regulate AI development.
Data from the Open Data Inventory (ODIN) shows that between 2020 and 2022, Zimbabwe’s score decreased from 48 to 42.

The overall score is a combination of a data coverage sub score and a data openness sub score, which measures how complete a country’s statistical offerings are and how well that data meets international standards of openness.

Freedom of information act On 1 July 2020, Zimbabwe adopted the Freedom of Information (FOI) Act10 to give effect to section 61 of the Constitution of Zimbabwe, which provides for the freedom of expression and freedom of the media.
gaps: There is a need to ensure that PPPs and other large-scale contracts or concessions do not result in unregulated exploitation of personal data or erosion of trust in AI-based systems.

While Zimbabwe’s Environmental and Climate Change Policy provides a foundational framework for environmental protection, further amendments to cover AI are required.
As AI technologies continue to evolve and be integrated into various sectors, their environmental implications are becoming increasingly apparent.

These could range from energy consumption, as AI algorithms often require substantial computational power, which can lead to increased energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions; to a significant environmental footprint, including land use, water consumption, and waste generation to operate dat

While Zimbabwe’s specific legislation may not directly address AI’s environmental impacts, there are several international frameworks that could provide guidance: • Paris Agreement: This international agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius.
AI can play a role in developing sustainable solutions to climate change.
strengths: • Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): The SDGs, adopted by the United Nations, outline a global agenda for sustainable development.
gaps: Social and cultural 22 ### Page 25 More men than women used a mobile phone or the internet to pay bills in 2021 Used a mobile phone or the internet to pay bills in the past year, by sex (% age 15+) Zimbabwe The gap in internet usage between men and women in Zimbabwe, 7, is larger than the gap of Sub

Sub-Saharan Africa Lower middle income Female Male 40% 60% 80% 23 ### Page 26 Environmental and sustainability costs Although Zimbabwe has an Environmental and Climate Change Policy26 , the policy does not discuss the impact of AI on the environment.
However, it is crucial to ensure that AI technologies themselves do not contribute to the problem.
This approach, while necessary, needs to be enhanced to be able to address the complex issues surrounding children’s well-being in the digital age.
There is a need for more proactive measures to educate children about online safety, foster digital literacy, and support their healthy development in the digital world.

Available at: https://faolex.fao.org/docs/pdf/zim203760.pdf 24 ### Page 27 Culture Although the National Museums and Monuments Act27 precedes AI, its protection of culture in Zimbabwe could be extended to AI, for example, through a ministerial instrument.

25:06 provides for the storage and preservation of protected historical records and the declaration and conservation of protected historical records.28 The framework has yet to be updated to cover the digital age.

While African countries are pushing for regulations (relating to gene sequencing) that impede the flow of information, the European Seed Association offers a different view—a study on the use of digital sequence information on genetic resources in Germany.29 Zimbabwe has not yet implemented any poli
It has yet to pass a specific law protecting minority languages and cultures in the offline environment.
While there have been periods of improvement, particularly between 2012 and 2016, the country’s overall score needs to improve to match the global and regional averages.

findings: Some of the links used include research output, ethical AI research, innovation output etc.

Similarly, there is no publicly available dataset of education strategy, curriculum content, educational attainment, or public access to AI education other than what is stipulated in section 4.2 of this report.
Regarding AI talent, Zimbabwe’s education allocation is 14 per cent, and it is estimated that less than 5 per cent goes to R&D.

There are many Zimbabwean researchers on AI based outside the country, including Tapiwa Chiwewe, Mavis Machirori, Arthur Gwagwa, and James Manyika.

Still, if we interpret ethics more broadly, as we suggested earlier, the number will slightly increase to include researchers on data privacy from legal, human rights, and other social science angles.

strengths: To show its understanding of recent developments, the ICT Policy also contains plans to support AI development through enabling policies such as: • Developing comprehensive guidelines and legal frameworks for the responsible and ethical use of AI and emerging technologies like IoT and BDA.
gaps: However, some Zimbabweans based abroad have probably patented AI inventions, including Pasi William Sachiti, founder and CEO of Academy of Robotics, an autonomous technology company primarily known for developing street-legal self-driving vehicles and solutions for road maintenance.
However, this is below the Dakar Framework for Action, which recommends a 20 per cent budget threshold for the education sector.
As a key recommendation, the government needs to avail datasets on this dimension where some are available and implement data collection mechanisms where data has not been historically collected.
This positive momentum continued in subsequent years, although at a slower pace.
However, many rural and underserved areas in Zimbabwe face significant internet connectivity challenges, hampering the ability to provide quality computer science education45 .
Despite progress, internet penetration remains limited in Zimbabwean rural, formerly marginalized and underserved areas.
Costs are relatively affordable, but widespread access is lacking.
However, the lack of high-speed fixed broadband limits overall internet connectivity.
For businesses, data on business internet connectivity is insufficient, making it difficult to assess the extent of digital adoption in the commercial sector.

economic.title: Economic
findings: Available at: https://zimlii.org/akn/zw/act/2002/5/eng@2016-12-31 12 Criminal Law (Codification and Reform) Act [Chapter 9:23] No.

Available at: https://www.veritaszim.net/sites/veritas_d/files/Freedom%20of%20Information%20Act%20No.%201%20of%202020.pdf Zimbawe 48 ODIN SCORE 2020 42 ODIN SCORE 2022 COVERAGE SCORE Out of 100 2020 2022 46 32 OPENNESS SCORE Out of 100 2020 2022 50 51 16 ### Page 19 The data above is from the 2024 P
However, in June 2023, the Zimbabwean government adopted a “patriotic bill”, criminalizing any “attack on sovereignty and national interest”, a legislation that threatens the work of journalists.
The FOI Act, by promoting transparency and accountability in Zimbabwe, is central to the digital transformation and AI agenda.
It ensures that citizens have access to information about how AI is being used and its potential impacts.

AI monitoring, if not implemented carefully, could lead to violations of freedom of expression and privacy, while the FOI Act’s provisions for access to information can help ensure public oversight and accountability in the development and use of AI.
Zimbabwe’s Consumer Rights Competition Act 234, and Consumer Protection Act 235 serve as crucial foundational legislations for the development and implementation of AI within the country.
Establishing clear guidelines and regulations, these laws create a conducive environment for AI innovation while safeguarding the interests of consumers.
strengths: These Acts provide a comprehensive framework for protecting consumer rights, fostering fair competition, and ensuring the ethical use of technology.

Cyber and data protection act Laws and regulations On 3 December 2021, Zimbabwe adopted the Cyber and Data Protection Act.15 This Act provides for data protection with due regard to the Declaration of Rights under the Constitution and the public and national interest; establishes a cyber security ce

The Cyber and Data Protection Act designates the Postal and Telecommunications Regulatory Authority, established in terms of the Postal and Telecommunications Act, as the national data protection authority.
https://www.jsc.org.zw/upload/Acts/2014/1120done.pdf 18 ### Page 21 (POTRAZ), established under the Postal and Telecommunications Act, as the implementing authority.
Comprehensive data sharing legislation should also be established to create clear protocols for data exchange while safeguarding personal data.

Additionally, independent oversight bodies, instead of current government aligned entities, should be established to enhance the objectivity and fairness in implementing and enforcing freedom of information and data protection laws, along with protection for whistle blowers.
Some of the specific challenges include: • Resource constraints: Developing comprehensive AI regulations requires funding for research, expert consultations, public engagement, and policy drafting.
Considering this, Zimbabwe may face limitations in funding, technical infrastructure, and research capabilities necessary for robust AI policy development and implementation.
Building a team of experts knowledgeable about AI technology, its societal implications, and legal intricacies would go a long way in developing comprehensive AI regulations and policies.
• Infrastructure challenges: A recent assessment of Zimbabwe’s digital environment notes that several core infrastructure elements are in place to support more advanced digital services.
gaps: However, potential conflicts with other legislation, like the Criminal Law Act, may need to be addressed.

For example, a clause in the Act permits a person to ‘decompile’ a computer program “to obtain information needed to enable the program to operate with other programs.”14 The Act provides a legal framework for the protection of Intellectual Property (IP) rights in the country.

However, the increasing capabilities of AI to generate creative content raise questions about the ownership 14 See Part III, clause 40 of Zimbabwe - Copyright and Neighbouring Rights Act [Chapter 26:05] amended up to No.
Firstly, the lack of clear guidelines on copyright ownership for AI-generated works can lead to legal uncertainty and discourage investment in AI research and development.
Finally, the Act may not be well-suited to protect the rights of AI developers themselves, who may need to protect their algorithms and other IP associated with AI development.

Similarly, the Zimbabwe Media Commission (instead of a court or independent commission) is the authority responsible for administration of the FOI Act, including handling appeals.17 However, the government administers procurement policies and practices in coordination, especially given the massive i
However, government needs to cohere and unite the distributed practices and make them public.
The ICA does, however, treat terms “monitoring” and “interception” differently, as far as it only defines the latter.
The Act lacks provisions on how to handle copyright infringement or harmful AI-generated content hosted on encrypted platforms.
Since the Act does not address ownership of AI-generated works, it is unclear who can be held liable for copyright infringements or harmful content creation.

key_stats.context: n Zimbabwe by posting blogs and pseudonymous articles on state corruption and was followed by over 100,000 people. See analysis here: https://www.academia.edu/11751312/Are_privacy_and_expression_right

By offering access to high-performance computing clusters, it enables complex simulations, data analysis, and research projects that would otherwise be unattainable.

and Security • Ministry of Home Affairs and Cultural Heritage • Government commissions Timeline: 2025 National AI Strategy: Main Policy

achievements.achievement: The Government of Zimbabwe has recognised the pivotal role of the Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR) technologies—such as AI, blockchain, and the Internet of Things (IoT)—in propelling economic growth and innovation.

To systematically exploit the potential of ICTs for natural development, Zimbabwe through the MICPCS developed a Smart Zimbabwe 2030 Master Plan with the key pillars anchored on; policy, regulation and statutes; secure and shared infrastructure; partnerships, skills and capacity building; content development; and confidence and security of network services.

It will be implemented through key specific sector-focused integrated pillars that will create a Smart Solutions ecosystem and these include Smart Brains, Smart Government; Smart Cities; Smart Agriculture; Smart Education; Smart Transport; Smart Health; Smart Tourism; and Smart Mining; among others.
Zimbabwe Govt Selects CloudWalk for Mass Facial Recognition Project.

AI monitoring, if not implemented carefully, could lead to violations of freedom of expression and privacy, while the FOI Act’s provisions for access to information can help ensure public oversight and accountability in the development and use of AI.
This Act helps to ensure that AI systems are developed and deployed in a manner that is safe and beneficial to consumers.
This Act protects various origins, including built heritage, rock art, paleontological materials, and sites.

While African countries are pushing for regulations (relating to gene sequencing) that impede the flow of information, the European Seed Association offers a different view—a study on the use of digital sequence information on genetic resources in Germany.29 Zimbabwe has not yet implemented any policy regarding using AI to preserve minority and Indigenous languages.

Zimbabwe should also partake and inform global discussions on the use of AI in law enforcement, for example, addressing bias and discrimination in facial recognition technologies, and in the military, for example, the use of algorithms and AI-enabled decision support systems.
The Permanent Secretary is a senior civil servant in the ministry responsible for the administrative and operational aspects of the ministry, ensuring policies are implemented effectively.
